title: Rewriting My Narrative: My Diagnosis Story

content: When I was 12, I developed pain in my wrists. It was dismissed by my pediatrician as "growing pains.” Slowly, it became widespread in my muscles and joints. It took over a year to be properly diagnosed with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis and fibromyalgia.
My treatment consisted of high-dosage NSAIDS to control my arthritis, muscle relaxers for my fibromyalgia, and a pamphlet full of stretching positions.
My life was never the same after this.
Fibromyalgia is the diagnosis I have the most trouble identifying with. How was I to reconcile, at 13 years old, that I’d spend the rest of my life in pain and fatigue?
When I looked up patient experiences, there were very few, and they were mostly centered around “grieving your old self.”  At that age, I’d barely had the chance to become a "self" yet.

It’s hard not to look back on my diagnosis and treatment with frustration. The average age for a fibromyalgia diagnosis is 30. Surely, my age should’ve been a major cause for concern. My doctor said to me, "If there was a magic pill I could give you to make this go away, I would.”

content_blocks.text: When I was 12, I developed pain in my wrists. It was dismissed by my pediatrician as "growing pains.” Slowly, it became widespread in my muscles and joints. It took over a year to be properly diagnosed with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis and fibromyalgia.
My treatment consisted of high-dosage NSAIDS to control my arthritis, muscle relaxers for my fibromyalgia, and a pamphlet full of stretching positions.
My life was never the same after this.
Fibromyalgia is the diagnosis I have the most trouble identifying with. How was I to reconcile, at 13 years old, that I’d spend the rest of my life in pain and fatigue?
When I looked up patient experiences, there were very few, and they were mostly centered around “grieving your old self.”  At that age, I’d barely had the chance to become a "self" yet.

It’s hard not to look back on my diagnosis and treatment with frustration. The average age for a fibromyalgia diagnosis is 30. Surely, my age should’ve been a major cause for concern. My doctor said to me, "If there was a magic pill I could give you to make this go away, I would.”

content: But I was never looking for a magic pill. I was looking for guidance on managing a life of chronic pain.

Years of NSAIDs and stretching gave me irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and some extra flexibility, but they didn’t help me in the long run.  There’s no cure for fibromyalgia, but that doesn’t mean there aren't options for improving my quality of life.
Most doctors were not prepared to support my diagnosis.

When my arthritis eventually went into remission, I stopped seeing the rheumatologist who diagnosed my fibromyalgia. My other doctors over the years reacted differently about my fibromyalgia. Some seemed relieved to hear that diagnosis because it meant they could write off my symptoms and do nothing for me. Two doctors told me “fibromyalgia doesn’t exist.”
I was either denied care or denied my diagnosis.

Even outside of doctor's offices, identifying with my diagnosis felt impossible. I was always a high-achiever, involved in multiple extracurriculars, at the top of my class, and kept an active social life. You couldn’t tell that I’d need multiple days of recovery after the most mundane teenage activities. Going to an amusement park put me out of commission for almost a week.

content: Being diagnosed at such a young age, I felt I had no choice but to normalize my pain and fatigue. So I just never slowed down.

But when the world was forced to slow down in 2020, I slowed down with it. I was in my early 20s and finally realizing the toll that fighting fibromyalgia had on my body. I began to manage my chronic pain with nutrition and healthy lifestyle choices.
After 3 years, I can confidently say I’ve reduced my chronic pain by more than half by transforming my lifestyle.
A major part of my healing journey has been radical self-acceptance and forgiveness. I used to feel trapped in my body. I spent my teenage years fighting against it.
It took discipline, restraint, and a lot of maturing to learn to listen to my body.

As I continue to listen to my body and make choices that nourish my well-being, I’m rewriting my story from one of pain and limitation to a narrative of empowerment and strength. I'm facing my 13-year-old self and letting her know she can finally rest and doesn’t need to fight anymore.

After 3 years, I can confidently say I’ve reduced my chronic pain by more than half by transforming my lifestyle.
A major part of my healing journey has been radical self-acceptance and forgiveness. I used to feel trapped in my body. I spent my teenage years fighting against it.

As I continue to listen to my body and make choices that nourish my well-being, I’m rewriting my story from one of pain and limitation to a narrative of empowerment and strength. I'm facing my 13-year-old self and letting her know she can finally rest and doesn’t need to fight anymore.

content: I’m letting her know that I never gave up on us before, and I won’t now. Not only am I taking back my story, I’m taking back my autonomy.
Join others in the fibromyalgia community by joining our Fibromyalgia Facebook Group.
Photo Credit: Ezaka RAKOTONDRAMANANA
